Samsung really dropped the ball when they failed to introduce their Snapdragon line without 2-in-1 capability.  The Samsung Notes application is a brilliant bit of work and adds a lot of value to the Samsung brand.  Without 2-in-1 capability, the Samsung Notes app for handwriting is useless on their laptops.  It isn't as though Samsung would have to reinvent new tech.  They already had the chassis, hinge and software.  All they had to do was deliver the 2-in-1 competitive edge that would have made their Snapdragon offering a must have, particularly for those already invested in the Samsung ecosystem.    As it stands, I skipped the Samsung offering and went with the 13" Microsoft Surface laptop.   Great device and would be even better if I could use Microsoft Journal.  Sadly, while the Microsoft laptop is a very high quality device, it suffers the same handwriting limitation as all of the other Snapdragon devices.

I had lots of glitches with my surface laptop 7. 
Setup: Two 23" 1080p/60hz monitors connected by surface dock 2. 
-Often found computer under full load when in sleep mode (fans running full speed and computer very warm to touch).
-Resuming from sleep had changed resolution to one monitor often, and unplugging plugging back in sometimes worked.
-Microsoft native ARM apps struggled to open/work at all.  Looking at you Teams (ARM) app.

I have the Thinkpad T14s 12core snapdragon, 32GB ram, 1TB nvme. I liked it over the other Lenovo's, because of the port options, and correct location of the FN key. It's as quick to render video(h.264) as any nvidia equipped(3050 mobile, or ARC) xps I've used, but absolutely cannot scrub through video without proxies. I know it was never designed to do this. I just went with this option as all the other Intel/AMD options felt like an iteration from last year, in the same case(because they are).

I'm so far extremely happy with my 13.8 inch Surface Laptop 7 with X Plus. For someone who has a gaming desktop, it's a perfect companion device for mobile work and browsing. I would be happy to have better gaming performance and compatibility, and generally I might prefer to have a Zen 5 architecture device, but as a whole package it's incredible. For the first time in my life I actually enjoy using the trackpad, even clicking on it. Previously I couldn't imagine not wanting to use a mouse with a laptop, but this is just perfect.

Also, it feels super fast & snappy for general use. :)
The speaker test was awesome!

What is the point of doing all those benchmarks and comparison based on performance when the final recommendation is to use it for light tasks like office, web and movie watching. Intel and amd processors from 3 years ago can do these tasks equally well. I think the target audience is much better served by finding a heavily discounted version of premium laptops from 2 or 3 years ago. The only hit will be battery life.

Bought a Slim 7x and a X1 carbon both configured about the same. Sent the X1 back. The Yoga is going to Africa on Safari with me. My "big" laptop is an MSI Z16 with an i9 and 32GB RAM. My Desktop is built i7 with 64GB RAM. So far the Yoga does 90% of what the other two do albeit a little slower. Biggest down as a wildlife photographer, is that the Yoga runs LR and PS native, but LrC in emulation. The Yoga has a hard time with the AI Sharpening and noise reduction in all the above plus Luminar Neo, and Topaz PAI and DxO  PR4 don't run at all. Just my $0.02. Love your reviews.

Useless ARM computers, I have no doubt that the chip inside is good, but what insults the intelligence is that Windows on ARM is heavy garbage and that there is nothing useful for it that would justify the purchase of such a computer. Unless you're a masochist who specifically wants that chip to use a web browser on it. There are ultrabook computers with real chips inside x86 that can do much more for the same money and there is no way that ARM chip can surpass them, primarily because of the software support in the form of programs. The biggest culprits for the decline of the market are currently Apple and Microsoft, everything in the development of hardware is at a standstill because of those two companies, their demise would bring real freshness and progress to the market.
Shnapdragon laptops are Best to make a hype on internet, but not much more. General recommendation would be to avoid any of them
I know these are ARM chips but surely AMD have the power to combine these with Nvidia GPU's to get into the gaming side when needed and then more Macbook Pro qualities when not

Thinking of maxing out 13.8 inch surface with 32 gigs of ram and 1td of hd. Seeing this video discouraged me a bit. Want something that can breeze through heavy excels and raw dslr photo editing (hobby). What do you think? Don’t want 15inch coz portability is important too.

1:56 I am quite surprised that the new AMD Ryzen AI processors offer similar performance to Snapdragon at the same wattage, but their battery life is much worse than Snapdragon. Maybe AMD needs better tuning or drivers to improve the efficiency during light tasks on Windows. 

Given these useful graphs, I would expect a video that compares the processors with each other in terms of battery life and performance at different power levels. With this efficiency of the new Ryzen AI processors, going for Snapdragon may not be worth due to its compatibility issues and low graphics performance. What's also important is that, the Snapdragon processors may slow down GUI animations, scrolling, or window management operations (like the Task View) when multiple high-resolution monitors are used.

I love the promise of these ARM SoCs but far more software desperately needs to be ported over to Windows on ARM.  It's bad enough that I'd suggest that Microsoft just give away dev tools or flat out pay developers to port their apps over.  Yes, it's not an ideal move for MS' balance sheet in the short term, but if they don't do something drastic it's gonna take a very long time (if ever) for WoA to be any sort of real competition for Apple's MacOS.

You forgot to add Optimus for the Laptops that are leaker in performance like RTX 3050 or Ti (And other previous generations) when its not plugged in it will use the Integrated graphics(of the processor) rather than the actual GPU when its plugged in (rtx 3050 ti in this case). Laptops that have an Option to disable Optimus and use the Dedicated GPU like RTX 3060 and above  Can run more demanding games without being plugged in the wall with the power chord. (It can be a problem because it switches from integrated to Dedicated Automatically when you dont want to for example: 
Oculus Air Link app for PC doesnt recognize the Dedicated GPU rtx 3050 ti and uses the integrated graphics of the processor (even when plugged in) since Optimus manages that Directly and you cant do anything, unless your Laptop supports manual control of it,which gives horrible performance when trying to use the Headset unless using the cable directly )
Nice video but currently I am planning to buy desktop i5 14th gen.

Buyers, do yourselves a favour and buy a laptop with at least 3 SSD slots and install the system and important data/apps on 2x 500GB SSDs with RAID-1. This will prevent a total system crash if a system SSD fails. 
Use the third slot for a large capacity drive for data that's less important.
A great combo currently is i7-12800h and RTX 4050 6GB

Almost all reviewers like you ignore certain aspects that are essential to me:

- Notch. I will never buy any. This means that current Macbooks are not, although reviewers suggest, equally worth comparing to other devices.

- If devices have fans, their cleaning must be easy or I do not buy them.

- Batteries must have easy replacement, acceptable prices and manufacturer statements on long availability. Otherwise, I do not buy any device other than cheap ones.

- Keyboards must provide a typing experience similar to a mechanical desktop keyboard. Whenever, however, I try countless keyboards of mobile devices in stores, even the best ones are unacceptable crap. I cannot use such. Maybe Cherry MX Low Profile would be acceptable but I cannot know because such is never shown in stores here and some manufacturers only offer it with US layout while I need German layout.

- Ergonomics includes ordinarily sized arrow keys and four page navigation keys. Keyboards without such I do not buy.

Although the mining and Corona crisis prevented me from building an RTX 3000 desktop, above criteria meant that no mobile device was acceptable. With a 3 years delay, I built an RTX 4000 desktop. Seeing current mobile devices, nothing has changed - they are still unacceptable because of not fulfilling above criteria. If this state of the market continues, I will upgade my desktop instead of buying a mobile device. All those comparison reviews are immaterial as long as not all of my essential criteria above are fulfilled. You reviewers act on the assumption that there would be some mobile devices worth buying. This is not the case for users like me who have to resort to desktops despite their disadvantage of immobility. --robert jasiek

Well. I was looking for something around 1500US. Went to store and tried bunch of them. I discovered that for my regular use, I still need only FullHD resolution. All my videos are in FullHD or even less. In our country all TV show are in that resolution. SnapDragon speed is amazing but FullHD or 720p are not so good on 3K displays. I found that some 4K videos look better on just FullHD. Same is on Apple systems. I thought i ll switch (after 30 y of Win) but new Surface works and feels so damn good. I know they never be in just FullHD, so maybe some day SnapDragon will be. Its ok, I have 2y old Yoga and it is fine, just the fan noise is killing me. Maybe I was to long but I think that fan noise and resolution are important factors. My old concert videos look kind a shitty on 3K or even 2K.

I don't agree with what was said about the Macbook Air being the best general choice. I just looked into getting one, and it's such an obscene, obsolete product I think. The base price is high to begin with, and the default configuration of 8GB RAM and 256GB storage is nothing else than a complete insult, with upgrade prices being a downright robbery. So, for 1600-1800 dollars/euros you end up with a product that has 16GB RAM, only 512GB storage, with a soldered SSD that can brick your device easily, combined with a 60 Hz LCD display. That's a lot of compromises for a somewhat longer battery life. Meanwhile competing laptops offer similar build quality, 16GB RAM in the base config, 120Hz OLED screen, replaceable/uprgradeable SSD, perhaps even 2-in-1 functionality, at a significantly lower price.

My tip, Dont buy an expensive gaming laptop (4080/90) right now. The new 5080/90 equipped gaming laptops will be revealed at CES 2025 in January. Obviously, if you're a rich git and change laptops every year, feel free to ignore my tip 😊
